answers.text: movement to translate English and European texts

qas.question: What came to be valued over previous convolutions?

answers.text: new words, simplified syntax, and directness

qas.question: Who expressed skepticism regarding the transformation of Arabic?
What was legitimate knowledge no longer defined by?
What was a neologism expressing the introduction of new ideas via translation?

plausible_answers.text: The movement to translate English and European texts

qas.question: What kept Arabic languages the same?

plausible_answers.text: new words, simplified syntax, and directness

qas.question: What came to be hated over previous convolutions?
Who expressed hostility regarding the transformation of Arabic?
What was fake knowledge no longer defined by?
What was not considered a neologism expressing the introduction of new ideas via translation?

context: <b5_0>The <a0_0>movement to translate English and European texts<b5_0/><a0_0/> transformed the Arabic and Ottoman Turkish languages, and <a1_0><b6_0>new words, simplified syntax, and directness<b6_0/><a1_0/> came to be valued over the previous convolutions. <a2_0><b7_0>Educated Arabs and Turks<b7_0/><a2_0/> in the new professions and the modernized civil service expressed skepticism, writes Christopher de Bellaigue, "with a freedom that is rarely witnessed today.... No longer was legitimate knowledge defined by <a3_0><b8_0>texts in the religious schools<b8_0/><a3_0/>, interpreted for the most part with stultifying literalness. It had come to include virtually any intellectual production anywhere in the world." One of the neologisms that, in a way, came to characterize the infusion of new ideas via translation was "darwiniya", or "<a4_0><b9_0>Darwinism<b9_0/><a4_0/>".
